Could not find any MP3 files in the Soundwalker folder!

Invalid MP3 name format!

Correct: latitude,longitude,radius1,radius2.mp3

		latitude and longitude in degrees
		radius1: active radius in meters
		radius2: fade-in radius in meters

Example: 42.90895,-78.87955,48,24.mp3

Other Order (2014)
Teri Rueb

"Other Order" is a sound walk set in the abandoned ruderal landscape of Bussey Brook Meadow. Where the formal gardens of the Arboretum present visitors with carefully arranged and maintained specimens organized according to formal systems of botanical classification, Bussey Brook Meadow is a less easily categorized “emergent” ecology – an urban wild that has evolved through informal processes of management that have left it open to colonization by spontaneous vegetation, and the ever-shifting impacts of human interventions.

Resilience is the hallmark of such emergent ecologies, as illuminated by the voice of retired Senior Research Scientist, Peter Del Tredici, as heaccompanies a variety of guest visitors on walks through the meadow.

The tracts that make up the contemporary Bussey Brook Meadow parcel have been owned and governed by disparate parties since the 1600s, including private farmers and residents, Harvard University, the Bussey Institute and the City of Boston. Designated as an “urban wild” in the 1970s, and later brought together as a unified parcel, the site became part of the Arnold Arboretum indenture in the mid-1990s and was made passable with the opening of the Blackwell Footpath in 2001, named after John Blackwell, an urban planner who dedicated over 30 years to the preservation of urban wilds throughout Boston.

Bussey Brook Meadow is now managed as a living laboratory for urban ecology. It is a site where human interventions including agriculture, landfills, sewer and transportation corridors interact with biological processes and together they are allowed to run their "natural" course. Despite a long history of abuse and neglect, the site has evolved to its current state as a functional urban wetland. The careful observer will be rewarded with discoveries both delightful and disturbing in this “arboretum gone wild”.

The app is a GPS-enhanced software that senses the participant's movement and location in the landscape and plays back pre-recorded sounds at various points through the landscape. Visitors are encouraged to download the app in advance of their visit and wear headphones for optimal listening. Be mindful of bicyclists and other pedestrians on the trail as you wear headphones!

Further information about the project may be found at:
http://www.terirueb.net/other_order/index.html

Credits:
		Created by Teri Rueb
Sound Design:
		Ernst Karel
Additional Sound Samples:
		Adam McFillin
Mobile App Development:
		Tom Stoll (iOS)
		Nima Vakili (Android)
Illustration:
		Alison Paul

Other Order was commissioned by the Arnold Arboretum and partially funded by the Harvard metaLab.

Enregistrez vos déplacements pour partager vos parcours et contribuer au projet Grimpant :

Appuyez sur le bouton «Commencer le parcours» pour débuter l'enregistrement de vos déplacements à travers la ville.


Plantez une graine pour faire entendre votre voix dans le projet Grimpant :

Pendant votre parcours, lorsque vous découvrez une plante ou un arbre qui vous semble remarquable, appuyez sur le bouton «Planter une graine» pour enregistrer votre commentaire audio sur la plante, l'arbre ou la vigne de votre choix (une minute maximum).

Appuyez sur le bouton «Écouter» pour réécouter votre enregistrement avant de l'envoyer. Grimpant vous propose ensuite d'envoyer votre enregistrement.


Écouter une graine :

Vous pouvez écouter les enregistrements des autres personnes en sélectionnant une graine sur la carte.
Section %1d is just a dummy section.
